page.title: 03FIVE CROSSES FARM (2)
page.content: The cows are milked again at 16.00h and are so well conditioned that they enter the parlour on hearing the radio! The milk yield per cow per day is 4 to 10 gallons. A veterinary surgeon calls twice a month. The busiest time is May 18 to June 15 when grass is collected and pickled in its own lactic acid. The 1200 tons of silage so formed is stored for winter fodder. A 6 volt electric fence regulates the cows' grazing. Anually the cattle are branded by a 'cold burn' from liquid nitrogen on the buttock. So each cow carries its own identity number as well as the farm's, in this case X1891,inside its ear. Manure is spread on the fields as fertilizer but the farmer would like to see research into better use of its valuable nutrients.
